Homarus gammarus , known as the European lobster or common lobster , is a species of clawed lobster from the eastern Atlantic Ocean , Mediterranean Sea and parts of the Black Sea . It is closely related to the American lobster , H. americanus . It may grow to a length of 60 cm ( 24 in ) and a mass of 6 kilograms ( 13 lb ) , and bears a conspicuous pair of claws . In life , the lobsters are blue , only becoming " lobster red " on cooking . Mating occurs in the summer , producing eggs which are carried by the females for up to a year before hatching into planktonic larvae . Homarus gammarus is a highly esteemed food , and is widely caught using lobster pots , mostly around the British Isles . 
 Homarus gammarus is a large crustacean , with a body length up to 60 centimetres ( 24 in ) and weighing up to 5 – 6 kilograms ( 11 – 13 lb ) , although the lobsters caught in lobster pots are usually 23 – 38 cm ( 9 – 15 in ) long and weigh 0 @.@ 7 – 2 @.@ 2 kg ( 1 @.@ 5 – 4 @.@ 9 lb ) . This may occur several times a year for young lobsters , but decreases to once every 1 – 2 years for larger animals . 
 The first pair of pereiopods is armed with a large , asymmetrical pair of claws . The larger one is the " crusher " , and has rounded nodules used for crushing prey ; the other is the " cutter " , which has sharp inner edges , and is used for holding or tearing the prey . Usually , the left claw is the crusher , and the right is the cutter . 
 The exoskeleton is generally blue above , with spots that coalesce , and yellow below . The red colour associated with lobsters only appears after cooking . This occurs because , in life , the red pigment astaxanthin is bound to a protein complex , but the complex is broken up by the heat of cooking , releasing the red pigment .

The female carries the eggs for up to 12 months , depending on the temperature , attached to her pleopods . Females carrying eggs are said to be " berried " and can be found throughout the year . 
 The eggs hatch at night , and the larvae swim to the water surface where they drift with the ocean currents , preying on zooplankton . This stage involves three moults and lasts for 15 – 35 days . After the third moult , the juvenile takes on a form closer to the adult , and adopts a benthic lifestyle .  Air Vice Marshal Frank Headlam , CB , CBE ( 15 July 1914 – 23 December 1976 ) was a senior commander in the Royal Australian Air Force ( RAAF ) . Born and educated in Tasmania , he joined the RAAF as an air cadet in January 1934 . He specialised in flying instruction and navigation before the outbreak of World War II . In April 1941 , he became commanding officer of No. 2 Squadron , which operated Lockheed Hudsons . The squadron was deployed to Dutch Timor in December , and saw action against Japanese forces in the South West Pacific . After returning to Australia in February 1942 , Headlam held staff appointments and training commands , finishing the war a group captain .

His tenure as DCAS coincided with the most significant rearmament program the Air Force had undertaken since World War II , and with manpower shortages stemming from this expansion and from Australia 's increasing involvement in the security of South East Asia . The city's economy flourished due to the thriving railway industry, with goods transported along these lines contributing significantly to its economic growth. The land now known as Meridian was once inhabited by the Choctaw Native Americans. The area was ceded to the United States in 1830 through the Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek, which was signed during the Indian Removal Period. Following the ratification of the treaty, European-American settlers began to settle in the region.

Richard McLemore, the first settler of Meridian, secured a federal land grant of approximately 810 hectares, which he used to attract more settlers and develop the area. In 1853, most of McLemore's land was acquired by Lewis A. Ragsdale, a lawyer from Alabama. John T. Ball, a merchant from Kemper County, later purchased the remaining 32 square kilometers. As a result of these acquisitions, Ragsdale and Ball became known as the founders of the city, and they began laying out lots for new development on their respective land sections.

As the residents of the city eagerly awaited the naming of their new settlement, intense debates erupted over the most fitting title. Ball and the industrious denizens of the region, deeply entwined with the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, rallied behind the name "Meridian," cherishing its symbolic connection to "junction." On the other hand, the agrarian populace of the city preferred "Unknown" (meaning "mad river" in a Native American language), echoing the spirit of the nearby creek. Ragsdale, too, staunchly advocated for "Ragsdale City."  Ball, a visionary determined to showcase his railroad prowess, erected a grand station house on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, where the sign would alternate daily between "Meridian" and "Unknown." As the years passed, the rapid development of the railroads attracted a wave of railroad workers, who eventually overpowered the other factions in the city. Their voices prevailed, and "Meridian" found a permanent place on the station sign.  Finally, on February 10, 1860, the city was officially incorporated as "Meridian." The historic event marked the culmination of years of spirited debates and the triumph of the railroad's influence over the community.

At the onset of the American Civil War in 1861, Meridian was a small village situated at a pivotal railroad junction. This strategic location prompted the Confederate forces to construct numerous military installations to bolster their war efforts. The Battle of Meridian in 1864 saw General William Tecumseh Sherman leading his troops into the city, annihilating the railroads and destroying an arsenal, along with enormous storehouses. His forces subsequently torched numerous buildings to the ground. In a post-battle statement, Sherman reportedly remarked, "Meridian, along with its depots, storehouses, arsenal, hospitals, offices, hotels, and cantonments, no longer exists." Despite the devastation, the railroad lines in the city were expeditiously repaired and resumed operation within a mere 26 working days following the battle. However, racial tensions persisted during the Reconstruction era, culminating in the 1871 riot that decimated many businesses.

As the town emerged from the shadows of the Civil War, it embarked on a remarkable journey of prosperity. The "Golden Age" of Meridian flourished from 1880 to 1910, when the burgeoning railroads facilitated rapid growth and attracted a flood of industries. This economic boom sparked a remarkable population surge, which subsequently ignited the commercial dynamism of the downtown area. By 1890, Meridian had risen to become the preeminent city in Mississippi and a pivotal hub for manufacturing in the Southern United States. Throughout this golden era, countless historical landmarks were erected, including the opulent Grand Opera House in 1890, the esteemed Wechsler School in 1894, two illustrious Carnegie libraries in 1913, and the awe-inspiring <unk> Building, Meridian's awe-inspiring skyscraper, in 1929.

The city's growth was facilitated by the commission government's initiatives, which led to the establishment of 90 new industrial plants in 1913 and a thriving automobile industry in the 1920s. As a result, the S.H. Kress & Co. building, designed to provide luxury to the common man, opened in downtown Meridian, as did the Temple Theater, which operated as a movie house. The federal courthouse was constructed in 1933 as part of a Works Progress Administration (WPA) project.

Following a brief economic downturn towards the end of the Great Depression, the nation entered World War II, subsequently reaffirming the vital role of railroads in transportation. Essential for the movement of gasoline and scrap metal required for military vehicle production, Meridian regained its prominence as the region's rail hub. This period of renewed prosperity persisted until the 1950s, when the increased popularity of automobiles and the Interstate Highway System rendered passenger rail transportation less attractive. Consequently, the decline of the railroad industry led to significant job losses and a consequent population decline as workers migrated to other areas in search of employment.

During the tumultuous American Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s, Meridian, Mississippi was home to a Council of Federated Organizations (COFO) office, as well as several other activist organizations. James Chaney and other local residents, along with Michael Schwerner, his wife Rita, and Andrew Goodman, volunteers from the North, worked tirelessly to create a community center. This center aimed to empower the African American community by providing classes that would help them regain the right to vote. However, their efforts faced opposition from white residents, and racial tensions often resulted in violent confrontations. On June 1964, Chaney, Schwerner, and Goodman went to Neshoba County, Mississippi, to meet with members of a black church that had been bombed and burned. Tragically, the trio disappeared that very night while on their way back to Meridian. Following a massive FBI investigation, their murdered bodies were discovered two months later, buried in an earthen dam. This incident became a pivotal moment in the Civil Rights Movement, shedding light on the deep-rooted racial injustices that were prevalent in the United States. The story of the three young men serves as a poignant reminder of the sacrifices made by countless individuals during the struggle for equality and justice.

In the hallowed halls of the federal courthouse in Meridian, seven Klansmen, including a deputy sheriff, stood trial for their roles in the heinous crimes against the Mississippi civil rights workers. Their conviction for "depriving the victims of their civil rights" marked a pivotal moment in history, as it was the first time a white jury had brought justice to a white official in a civil rights killing.  In 2005, the case was reopened by the state, igniting renewed hope for justice. After lengthy investigations, Edgar Ray Killen was finally brought to account for his role in the murders. Convicted of manslaughter, he was sentenced to 60 years in prison, marking a turning point in the fight for equality.  Meridian, the site of these heinous crimes, honored James Chaney by renaming a portion of 49th Avenue in his honor and annually hosting a memorial service to remember his life and the lives of Goodman and Schwerner. In this way, the town stands as a testament to the resilience of the civil rights movement, and a reminder that justice can prevail when the truth is unearthed.

In the early days of Meridian's public education system, it was grounded on the foundations laid by the 1870 Mississippi Constitution. From 1870 to 1885, the City Council entrusted the Board of School Directors with the responsibility of overseeing the schools, which were responsible for the operation of the educational institutions. While there were several schools in the city before 1884, they were privately owned and limited in number, enrolling only a few hundred students. It was not until September 1884 that the city inaugurated its first publicly owned school. The first public school for African Americans in the city was established in rented facilities from St. Paul Methodist Church, a testament to the community's determination to provide education to all. The Mississippi Legislature took further steps to improve the city's educational infrastructure in January 1888, when they amended the city charter to enable the establishment of a municipal school district. In March of the same year, the city was granted permission to issue $30,000 worth of bonds, an unprecedented opportunity to build new public schools. As a result, the Wechsler School was constructed in 1894, marking the first brick-built public school in Mississippi designed specifically for the education of African Americans. This remarkable achievement demonstrated the city's commitment to providing quality education to all its citizens, regardless of race or socio-economic background.

As Meridian Public School District grew from its humble beginnings in this early district, it expanded to include 6 elementary schools, 3 middle schools, and 3 high schools. The city is home to several private schools such as Lamar School, Calvary Christian School, Community Christian School, and St. Patrick's Catholic School. The main high school, Meridian High School, occupies an impressive 37 acres, featuring 6 buildings and 111 classrooms. Offering grades 10 through 12, this institution serves a student population of approximately 1,500 young minds.

The island is comprised of a diverse array of volcanic and sedimentary rock formations dating back to the Devonian period.
